content.statement: A monad is an endofunctor M: C→C equipped with two natural transformations: unit (η: Id→M, also called return) and join (μ: M∘M→M, also called flatten), satisfying coherence laws.

explanation.intuition: A monad is a 'computational context' with two operations: return (put a value into the context) and join (flatten nested contexts). Think of Maybe: return wraps a value in Just, join flattens Just(Just(x)) to Just(x).
explanation.key_insight: Monads solve the problem of composing computations with effects. They provide a systematic way to chain operations that produce values in a context (optionality, lists, IO, state) while managing the context automatically.
explanation.technical_details: Formally, a monad (M, η, μ) on category C consists of: (1) Endofunctor M: C→C, (2) Natural transformation η: Id→M (unit), (3) Natural transformation μ: M∘M→M (join), satisfying: μ∘Mμ = μ∘μM (associativity) and μ∘Mη = μ∘ηM = id (identity).

formal_definition.latex: \text{A monad } (M, \eta, \mu) \text{ on category } \mathcal{C} \text{ consists of:} \\ \text{1. Endofunctor: } M: \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C} \\ \text{2. Unit: } \eta: \text{Id}_{\mathcal{C}} \Rightarrow M \\ \text{3. Join: } \mu: M \circ M \Rightarrow M \\ \text{satisfying coherence laws}
components: M: endofunctor mapping types to types
η (return/pure): wraps values in monad context

alternative_formulation.description: Monads can also be defined using bind (>>=) instead of join
alternative_formulation.bind_definition: bind :: M a -> (a -> M b) -> M b
alternative_formulation.relationship: join can be derived from bind and vice versa
alternative_formulation.equivalence:
join m = m >>= id
m >>= f = join (fmap f m)

programming_perspective.type_signature:
class Monad m where
  return :: a -> m a           -- unit
  (>>=)  :: m a -> (a -> m b) -> m b  -- bind
  join   :: m (m a) -> m a     -- join (can be derived)
programming_perspective.intuition: return puts a value in the context, >>= chains computations
